description:
Seriola dumerili, commonly known as the greater amberjack or yellowtail amberjack, is a species of large pelagic fish belonging to the family Carangidae. It is found in tropical and subtropical waters of the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans.

The greater amberjack is a streamlined, torpedo-shaped fish with a robust, elongated body. It can grow up to 2 meters in length and weigh up to 80 kilograms. The fish has a distinct yellow tail and dorsal fin, with a bronze-colored back and silvery-white underside. It is known for its impressive speed and strength, making it a popular target for recreational and commercial fisheries.

Seriola dumerili is a carnivorous species, feeding primarily on smaller fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods. It is an important predator in its ecosystem, helping to maintain the balance of marine communities. The greater amberjack is also a valuable commercial species, highly prized for its firm, flavorful flesh, which is commonly used in sashimi and other Japanese cuisine.

Conservation efforts are ongoing to ensure the sustainable management of Seriola dumerili populations, as overfishing and habitat degradation have led to declines in some regions. Understanding the biology and ecology of this species is crucial for effective fisheries management and the preservation of this important marine resource.
